top_comment.author: Cheryl D

comments.text:
+rek0v3r  Science is not a democracy 95% + scientists once agreed that the 
Earth was the center of the Universe, it only took one Copernicus to 
demonstrate that the Earth actually orbits the sun.

Can you please reference for me some empirical evidence, i.e. evidence that 
can be observed, measured and recreated with the same results that 
demonstrates causation between human activities and rising temperatures 
across the planet? Remember correlation doesn't equal causation, if you 
can't eliminate or at least mitigate all of the other variables in the 
climate equation when you are conducting your experiments, then you can't 
conclusively say that it was variable A rather than variable B (or C, D, E, 
F, and variables we don't even know of) that produced whatever outcome.

This problem gets worse when we try to create computer models to predict 
what will happen. We don't even fully understand what all of the variables 
are in the climate system, how can we hope to include all variables in a 
computer model of this system? Even if we did mitigate all the variables, 
the results that the model produces depend heavily on the programmed 
sensitivity to changing conditions, and to positive and negative feedbacks. 
These issues all arise without even questioning the data itself that is 
plugged into the model, and the IPCC data is indeed questionable.

You can label them as political if you want, but my comments have been much 
more focused on the reliability of the data and the models used by the 
IPCC. My arguments have been from a scientific and data analysis standpoint 
more than a politics standpoint, and you failed to actually address any of 
the points I brought up. What is the IPCC basing it's conclusion that 
humans are causing global warming off of if not computer models? If they 
can't "travel through time" to collect data, on what data are they basing 
such conclusions?

Also, I never placed blame on the US government or any specific government, 
though the US government is complicit in perpetuating the idea that science 
is a popularity contest.
comments.author: Brent Davila

comments.text:
+Brent Davila Gravity is just a theory... Walk off of a twenty story 
building and prove me wrong.

The rest of your wall of text is 100% USA political garbage. Just as I 
stated earlier. To any non-American (95% of the worlds population), you 
sound self righteous and ignorant. 

"The conclusions drawn by the IPCC are based on computer models, not 
empirical observation."

What a stupid statement. Shall they travel through time and collect data? 
It isn't all based around computer models, way to twist the truth and 
common logic on that one. Flat out bullshit.

Remove USA and its politics from AGW, and you have no argument. Your 
conspiracies of your government fooling us into global warming are 
laughably confusing on the global scale. As are your brainwashed fantasies 
of a solution by means of refined capitalism.
comments.author: rek0v3r

comments.text:
+rek0v3r Let me first start by saying that I don't believe these are 
theories, they are IN FACT theories, just like Special Relativity is just a 
theory and Gravity is just a theory. This is part of the problem I have the 
with AGW fervor, you can't claim that you are practicing sound science, and 
then claim that you are positive beyond any doubt in the same breath, the 
two are mutually exclusive.

 "Something that has never happened in such a short period of time void of 
a cataclysmic event..." Which is exactly my point, where is the empirical 
data that shows such rapid rises in CO2 cause rapid rises in global 
temperatures. The cases where there have been such rapid rises in CO2 have 
been coupled with extreme catastrophe that have thrown all sorts of other 
variables into the climate equation, so how can you pin down CO2 as the 
cause for any ensuing climactic shifts? By the same token, we have no 
baseline to judge what will happen with a rapid rise in CO2 that lacks 
those other catastrophic events. I have only seen computer models that 
extrapolate what happens at this point, we don't have anything empirical to 
go off of, so saying that we know what is happening for certain based off 
of the models the we created assumes that we accounted for all of the 
variables throughout the entire Earth's climate and created accurate models.

I have no great love for oil companies like you imply, I just don't see why 
we should alternatively trust information pushed by companies and 
governments that are just as corrupt. Mind you, I am not deriving any 
skepticism from data that I have seen perpetuated by oil companies, my 
skepticism comes from looking at the data and claims of people who say that 
humans are indeed causing global warming, like the IPCC reports. The 
conclusions drawn by the IPCC are based on computer models, not empirical 
observation. Their temperature readings and tree core samples which are 
"empirical" have been shown to be selectively chosen, and the temperature 
readings subject to things like the heat island effect. I live in Tempe, 
Arizona right next to ASU. On their campus is one of the temperature 
reading stations used in the IPCC reports, I have visited it, and it is in 
the middle of a black asphalt parking lot with a chain link fence around 
it, and the temperature probe is maybe 5 feet from the ground. On a hundred 
degree (F) day, that parking lot easily gets up to 110-115.

I can't wait until clean and abundant energy sources are made cheap and 
efficient enough for everyone to utilize them without having to mix 
politics and science by having governments subsidize such technologies. 
Unfortunately what we have now are expensive technologies subsidized and 
pushed by governments that aren't very efficient, and that frequently end 
up putting all sorts of nasty stuff into the environment themselves. The US 
economy and the stability and safety of the nation and it's populace is 
entirely dependent on fossil fuel. This is not a desirable situation, but 
it is a fact, and it is one that I would like to see changed as soon as 
possible. The problem still remains though that we can't simply drop oil, 
it will have to be a gradual process of replacing all of the infrastructure 
of the entire country. It should be done through free market capitalism and 
a desire for the populace to willingly buy into it. Also, for the record I 
don't support any government subsidization of any private company including 
when government covers the risk for exploratory drilling, subsidizes any 
product, or bails out any company or bank.
comments.author: Brent Davila

comments.text:
+Brent Davila How could I not? everyone is aware of it. just over 400 
ppm/0.04%. It got to that in just over a century from ~280ppm. Something 
that has never happened in such a short period of time void of a 
cataclysmic event such as a meteor or super volcano.

Your whole argument is based on comparisons to events that took hundreds of 
thousands, to millions of years to occur. You compare that to changes seen 
over a generation? 

I don't care to discuss with anyone as obtuse as yourself, who believes 
these facts regarding AGW are theories. Did you know that Al Gore is not a

laughs at fools like yourself mixing politics and science and your nemisis 
Al Gore? You think it is all a US government scam for a tax grab. There's 
no arguing with an oil shill such as yourself. Yes, you've been put in your 
place. You're just too delusional to recognize it yet. Stupid American...
comments.author: rek0v3r

comments.text:
+rek0v3r  You didn't actually make any argument to put me in any place. 
Your argument was essentially "Shut up you big dummy head," and you have 
only further demonstrated your childlike mentality by thinking that such a 
childish non-argument could be sufficient to put anyone "in their place." 
If you want to continue name-calling, and posting without addressing any 
actual points or facts, be my guest, you can talk to yourself all you want.

Now, if you would like to actually have a discussion about the theory of 
anthropogenic global warming, where we debate ideas based on facts and 
analyze data, I am more than happy to have that conversation. For starters 
I would ask, do you know what percentage of the Earth's atmosphere is 
comprised of CO2?

comments.author: ImagineCraft7

comments.text:
+Winchester85 You mean like the scientific fact and evidence to support 
that the Earth has gone through countless periods of extreme warming and 
cooling for billions of years before people even existed? Or the fact that 
there have been plenty of times during the history of our planet where CO2 
was far higher than it is today? There were even several occasions where 
our entire planet was locked in a thick ice sheet, and it sure didn't warm 
up because soccer moms were driving around SUV's. I am not denying that the 
climate changes, only that humans are the cause. If we are the cause, how 
do you explain the billions of years of extreme climate variation before we 
showed up? What is truly scary is that people who take a passing interest 
in science can be so easily convinced when, from a scientific perspective 
if you look at the peer reviewed papers the "evidence" for anthropogenic 
global warming is shaky at best, and not empirically established. 
Furthermore, this man-caused global warming hysteria is driven by 
hypocrites who make a ludicrous amount of money by guilting people into 
thinking they are destroying the planet. Of course they offer the solution 
to be guilt free you just have to give them more money through government 
subsidies, buy the cars, houses, lightbulbs, food, clothes, and whatever 
else they decide you should buy in order to "save the planet." They act 
like it is absolutely critical at this very moment that you reduce your 
carbon footprint no matter how much it costs you, and yet Al Gore flies 
just himself and his wife all over the world with his 16 passenger private 
jet spewing out deadly carbon dioxide all the way. Even if he has to do so 
in order to spread the word to save the planet, wouldn't it be more of a 
statement to just skype your appearance saying "I am skyping you to save 
the planet from the carbon dioxide it would have taken for me to fly 
there." I might even give him credit for that move. Sadly though, Al Gore 
and his ilk only want everyone else to change what they are doing because 
everyone else is destroying the planet; he and his buddies are saving it by 
raking in vast amounts of money from guilting and scaremongering gullible 
people.
comments.author: Brent Davila

top_comment.text:
CO2 global warming is utter nonsense.  We need to move toward more oxygen 
in our cities and more CO2 which has been proven to increase plant growth 
which in turn creates more oxygen. H20 vapor is a significant green house 
gas. CO2, by comparison not.  That said we need to prohibit adding toxic 
pollutants such as mercury and ionizing radiation to our environment. 
Hydrogen will increase oxygen in cities- coupled with other natural energy 
sources would make the US a net exporter of energy with super clean air and 
water in a short time frame.﻿

comments.text:
Before recent years CO2 global warming was largely discredited but now we 
have a series of misinformation events pushing the notion all caused by 
people who have their names on a market which will trade the 'right to 
pollute'. California enaged in a form of that buying back people's old cars 
and selling the right to pollute for the theoretical life of those cars to 
factories and requiring toxic addititives in gas to also allow such sales 
of rights to pollute which have lead to distruction of ground water 
supplies and increases in net pollution. The pollution market scam was used 
to make money not limit pollution. CO2 trading occording to Gore will never 
lead to a reduction in our dependence on oil- they have time after time 
effectively supported big oil whilst supporing this bogus carbon exchange 
based upon a totally bogus theory that man's contribution to CO2 can cause 
any significant global warming. It cannot. H2O in the atmostphere has lead 
to regional warming caused by plant life concentration.

It's just another example of why you should spend time uncovering reality.  
Man caused CO2 global warming is a lie designed by criminals that think 
government exists to scam- steal money. That is a conclusion based upon a 
long and exhaustive effort to know the truth.  Man's contribution to CO2 is 
not significant- total CO2 is not significant in terms of causing any 
degree of urgently dangerous global warming issues now or in the imaginable 
future.

In other words it is vailid to demand cleaning devices to  remove mercury 
from the exhaust of coal fired plants it is not valid to require removal of 
CO2 or restrict coal plants based upon CO2 creation or any other activity 
which adds or transfers CO2 to the atmosphere. We have had a net global 
cooling for at least 10 years if not 20.

Cities are oxygen starved in many areas. By breaking h2o into it's 
constituents one can actually increase atmospheric oxygen.
comments.author: TruthInjector

comments.text:
"CO2 global warming is utter nonsense" - I disagree, but please continue.

"We need to move toward more oxygen in our cities" - We do? Why?

"and more CO2 which has been proven to increase plant growth which in turn 
creates more oxygen. H20 vapor is a significant green house gas. CO2, by 
comparison not." - Agreed. However, on a planet whose surface is 71% liquid 
water, a vast quantity of water vapor is expected, isn't it? And isn't it 
rational to expect global temperatures to increase as we add other 
greenhouse gases, which in turn evaporate even more water from our oceans? 
Not to mention the melting of permafrost, thereby releasing CH4, which is a 
far more potent greenhouse gas than CO2?

"we need to prohibit adding toxic pollutants such as mercury and ionizing 
radiation to our environment" - Agreed. Although I don't see how this is in 
any way related to global warming, and I'm hypocritical enough that I will 
continue to use my microwave oven & plasma TV regardless.

"Hydrogen will increase oxygen in cities" - Huh? You lost me. It will? How? 
Where "will" this hydrogen come from? Electrolysis of water? But what about 
ionizing radiation? Steam reforming? Seems like you're a hypocrite too. 
Hydrogen production consumes energy, so to what gain is this?

"coupled with other natural energy sources would make the US a net exporter 
of energy with super clean air and water in a short time frame." You're 
joking right?

captions.text: Our world, Earth, is changing before our eyes.

Go back millions of years. Forests reached
into polar regions, sea levels rose, and temperatures

soared with high levels of the greenhouse
gas, carbon dioxide.

A long cooling period followed. But now CO2
is on the rise again. What will happen? How
will we live in the New World that's now emerging?

Scientists are intensively tracking the workings
of planet Earth with satellites that chart

its winds, ocean currents, temperatures, plant
growth, and more. And with a new virtual Earth,

shrunk down and converted into physical equations,
satellite data, and computer codes.

This other Earth, a mirror of the one in which
we live, is designed to follow the flow of

heat through the complex, dynamic engine known
as the climate, and to predict its future
evolution.

You can see the pattern of heat input in this
sequence showing surface temperatures. As

the seasons shift, heat builds and dissipates,
most notably across tropical and subtropical

regions. How does Earth dissipate this build
up of heat? Look below.

The oceans cover 71% of the planet's surface,
at an average depth of more than four kilometers.

They act like an immense battery that can
store and release energy over long periods

of time, while transporting heat from warm
to cool regions.

The oceans are set in motion by the unevenness
of solar heating, due to the amount of sunlight

striking the tropics versus the poles, along
with the cycles of day and night and the seasons.

That causes warm, tropical winds to blow toward
the poles, and cold polar air to push toward

the equator. Wind currents, in turn, drive
surface ocean currents. This computer simulation

shows the Gulfstream winding its way north
along the coast of North America.

This great ocean river carries enough heat
energy to power the industrial world a hundred

times over. It breaks down in massive whirlpools
that spread warm tropical waters over northern

seas. Below the surface, this current mixes
with cold deep currents that swirl around

undersea ledges and mountains. When heat builds
within tropical oceans in late summer, it
can be released in a fury.

Here is a simulation of surface winds beginning
on September 1, 2012. In that year, the Atlantic

Ocean spawned 19 named storms. These and other
smaller storms churned up a steady stream

of moisture that traveled north aboard immense
gyres of wind that circle the oceans.

Hurricane Sandy took shape over the Bahamas
on October 22nd. Moving north over the open

sea, it intensified within unusually warm
Gulf Stream waters. Up along the New Jersey

coastline, Sandy was slowed by a dome of high
pressure to the north. That caused it to turn

sharply west into an advancing cold front.
The combination brought damaging winds, heavy

rain, death, and a trail of destruction estimated
at 68 billion dollars.

Recent studies predict that as the oceans
continue to get warmer, they will release

their heat in ever more powerful, and more
frequent storms. As this virtual planet shows,

Earth's climate engine has a dazzling array
of moving parts: wind patterns and sea currents,

tides and terrain, that together help equalize
temperatures around the globe.
There's something else at work on our planet.

When sunlight bounces off the earth, water
vapor and cloud droplets absorb some of the

energy in the infrared portion of the spectrum,
transferring it to the rest of the atmosphere.

A recent NASA study predicted that if water
vapor were the only greenhouse gas, temperatures

would fall, sending Earth into an icebound
state.

Something is needed to act as a thermostat,
a control knob, to keep the climate steady.

Though it's only .038% of the atmosphere,
carbon dioxide absorbs enough energy to prop

up global temperatures and allow water to
remain in the atmosphere.

It's the settings on this thermostat that
are now changing. Since the industrial revolution,

the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased
nearly forty percent.

Thanks to our vantage point in space and our
virtual tools, we have a wide-angle view of

the New World that's emerging. However, causes
and effects are often jumbled in complex ways.

This sequence features a simulation of aerosols
in the atmosphere, fine particles from volcanoes,

fires, dust storms, cars, factories, and more.
These particles can have an impact on health,
as well as the overall climate.

Some particles, like sea salt, reflect sunlight
back into space. Others, like soot, absorb

heat and warm the atmosphere even as they
shade the Earth from solar rays.

Add in fires on the surface, detected by satellites
and shown here as red dots. They are major

producers of carbon soot. They are also a
catalyst for change in a warming world. Increased

CO2 and warmer weather will bring more rain
and vegetation to some places. In others,
they'll turn forests into tinderboxes.

Flash forward a century. How will Earth look
to us then? Will we, its supposed masters,

find ways to manage it? Or will we let it
slip from our grasp?
